key_insight: MemFlow introduces a flowing, adaptive memory mechanism that dynamically selects, compresses, and routes historical cues tailored to each upcoming video chunk, enabling consistent and efficient long-stream video narrative generation.
problem_solved: Maintains content consistency across long streaming video contexts by replacing static, one-size-fits-all memory compression strategies with per-chunk adaptive memory retrieval and updates.
method: Adaptive memory flow: a module that dynamically routes relevant historical cues to the generator for each to-be-generated chunk instead of using fixed compression rules.
Content-aware compression & retrieval: learned, task-conditioned compression and attention-based retrieval that preserve salient temporal details while reducing memory footprint.
Lightweight streaming updates: efficient incremental memory updates to support long narratives with lower compute and less drift over time.
impact: Makes long-video generation more coherent and scalable, reducing narrative drift and computational cost—useful for streaming video synthesis, long-form story generation, and real-time applications where maintaining temporal consistency is critical.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: input frames → adaptive MemFlow memory module (select/compress/route) → chunk generator, highlighting per-chunk routing decisions.
Memory flow animation: arrows showing historical cues flowing into memory, being compressed, and selectively fed to different future chunks.
Comparison chart: narrative consistency (e.g., fidelity/identity preservation) and compute/memory usage for MemFlow vs fixed-memory baselines.
Timeline visualization: long video timeline with annotations showing reduced drift and preserved details across distant frames when using MemFlow.
paper_title: MemFlow: Flowing Adaptive Memory for Consistent and Efficient Long Video Narratives
paper_authors: Sihui Ji, Xi Chen, Shuai Yang, Xin Tao, Pengfei Wan
